elements.content: A pseudo-rotaxane, [(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)2·H2O (1), and three polyrotaxanes, [Ag(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)3·8H2O (2), [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO3)3·10H2O (3), and [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])(H2O)][Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](ClO4)6·12H2O (4), are prepared with N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,6-hexanediamine (C6N3) or N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-benzenedimethylamine (BDMN3) incorporating cucurbit[6]uril (CB[6]) assisted by silver(I) ion. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that polyrotaxanes 2, 3, and 4 all have 1D linear chain structures with different shapes. Compounds 2 and 4 are square-wave shaped, while 3 is sawtooth-wave shaped. It is suggested that shapes of the 1D chains are mainly affected by flexibility of guest molecules, as well as the counteranions. Weak interactions between host/guest and inter-psuedo-rotaxanes help to generate infinite 2D and 3D structures from 1D chains of these polyrotaxanes.

elements.content: A pseudo-rotaxane, [(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)2·H2O (1), and polyrotaxanes, [Ag(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)3·8H2O (2), [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO3)3·10H2O (3), and [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])(H2O)][Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](ClO4)6·12H2O (4), were prepared and determined, in which N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,6-hexanediamine (C6N3) or N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-benzenedimethylamine (BDMN3) are incorporated in CB[6] assisted by silver(I) ions. The influence of flexibility and length of guest molecules, counterions, and weak interactions on the architectures of polyrotaxanes is discussed.

elements.content: Rotaxanes and polyrotaxanes have received considerable attention for a long time because of their specific topology, structures, and interesting properties, as well as the potential applications in the field of molecular devices and machines. Rotaxane is a supramolecular assembly consisting of three parts, rings, strings, and stoppers. The ring part usually includes varied types of organic hosts such as crown ethers, cyclopanes, calixarenes, and cyclodextrins among others. Cucurbit[6]uril (CB[6]) is a pumpkin-shaped macrocyclic compound and is composed of six symmetrically arranged glycoluril units covalently linked by twelve methylene bridges to form a rigid macro-cavitand with two highly polar carbonyl openings. The strong tendency to form host−guest complexes with aliphatic diammonium ions by ion−dipole and hydrogen-bonding interactions makes CB[6] attractive as a building block for the construction of polyrotaxanes, and many supramolecular assemblies such as one- (1D), two- (2D), three-dimensional (3D) structures and molecular necklaces have been reported. Although crystal structures of “guest−host” complexes of cucurbituril with p-xylylenediamine dihydrochloride or 4-methylpyridinium were determined by X-ray structure analyses, there is no report about the metal−organic frameworks with an aromatic group in the cavity of CB[6] up to now, and no crystal structures of pseudo-rotaxanes with a protonated diammonium ion incorporating CB[6] were available. In addition, more attention must be paid to the relationship between the constituent parts and the shapes of the polyrotaxanes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Rotaxanes and polyrotaxanes have received considerable attention for a long time because of their specific topology, structures, and interesting properties, as well as the potential applications in the field of molecular devices and machines. Rotaxane is a supramolecular assembly consisting of three parts, rings, strings, and stoppers. The ring part usually includes varied types of organic hosts such as crown ethers, cyclopanes, calixarenes, and cyclodextrins among others. Cucurbit[6]uril (CB[6]) is a pumpkin-shaped macrocyclic compound and is composed of six symmetrically arranged glycoluril units covalently linked by twelve methylene bridges to form a rigid macro-cavitand with two highly polar carbonyl openings. The strong tendency to form host-guest complexes with aliphatic diammonium ions by ion-dipole and hydrogen-bonding interactions makes CB[6] attractive as a building block for the construction of polyrotaxanes, and many supramolecular assemblies such as one- (1D), two- (2D), three-dimensional (3D) structures and molecular necklaces have been reported. Although crystal structures of "guest-host" complexes of cucurbituril with p-xylylenediamine dihydrochloride or 4-methylpyridinium were determined by X-ray structure analyses, there is no report about the metal-organic frameworks with an aromatic group in the cavity of CB[6] up to now, and no crystal structures of pseudo-rotaxanes with a protonated diammonium ion incorporating CB[6] were available. In addition, more attention must be paid to the relationship between the constituent parts and the shapes of the polyrotaxanes.

elements.content: To further investigate the effects of flexibility and length of guests, counterions, etc. on shapes of polyrotaxanes with CB[6], we designed and synthesized an aliphatic and an aromatic diaminoalkane guest, that is, N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,6-hexanediamine (C6N3) and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-benzenedimethylamine (BDMN3) (Scheme ), and prepared a pseudo-rotaxane and polyrotaxanes of them with CB[6] and different silver salts. Herein, we report the crystal structures of a pseudo-rotaxane, [(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)2·H2O (1), and three silver(I) ion assisted polyrotaxanes incorporating CB[6], namely, [Ag(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)3·8H2O (2), [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO3)3·10H2O (3), and [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])(H2O)][Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](ClO4)6·12H2O (4). The influence of flexibility and length of guest molecules, counterions, and intra- and intermolecular weak interactions on the architectures of polyrotaxanes will be discussed.

Herein, we report the crystal structures of a pseudo-rotaxane, [(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)2⋅H2O (1), and three silver(I) ion assisted polyrotaxanes incorporating CB[6], namely, [Ag(H2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO3)3⋅8H2O (2), [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO3)3⋅10H2O (3), and [Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])(H2O)][Ag(H2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](ClO4)6⋅12H2O (4). The influence of flexibility and length of guest molecules, counterions, and intra- and intermolecular weak interactions on the architectures of polyrotaxanes will be discussed.

elements.content: General Methods. All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the Analysis Center of Nanjing University. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Brucker DRX500 NMR spectrometer. C6N3 was synthesized according to literature procedures15 just replacing 1,4-butadiamine with 1,6-hexanediamine. BDMN3 and CB[6] were prepared by procedures reported previously.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Methods. All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the Analysis Center of Nanjing University. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Brucker DRX500 NMR spectrometer. C6N3 was synthesized according to literature procedures15 just replacing 1,4-butadiamine with 1,6-hexanediamine. BDMN3 and CB[6] were prepared by procedures reported previously.

elements.content: Caution: Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive and should be handled with care. All procedures for synthesis and measurements of the silver(I) complexes were carried out in dark.

elements.content: Preparation of [(H 2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 2 ·H 2 O (1). A mixture of CB[6] (2.90 g, 2.91 mmol) and [H4 C6N3](NO3)4 (1.00 g, 1.82 mmol) in water (40 mL) was heated at 50 °C for 8 h. After the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight, the undissolved CB[6] was filtered off. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuo to give a colorless solid of pseudo-rotaxane named [PR63](NO 3 ) 2 in which [H 2 C6N3] 2+ was incorporated into the cavity of CB[6]. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of 1 were obtained from a solution of [PR63](NO 3 ) 2 (79.2 mg, 0.055 mmol) in 5 mL of water by methanol diffusion after 2 weeks (36%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O):  δ 9.24 (s, 2H), 9.03 (d, 2H), 8.91 (d, 2H), 8.22 (t, 2H), 5.71 (d, 12H), 5.60 (d, 12H), 4.74 (s, 4H), 4.34 (d, 12H), 3.14 (t, 4H), 0.82 (m, 4H), 0.52 (m, 4H). Anal. Calcd for C54H64N30O18·7H2O:  C, 41.91; H, 5.08; N, 27.16. Found:  C, 41.75; H, 4.78; N, 27.06.

elements.content: [Ag(H 2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 3 ·10H 2 O (3). A mixture of CB[6] (3.98 g, 4.00 mmol) and [H4 BDMN3](NO3)4 (1.71 g, 3.00 mmol) in water (50 mL) was refluxed for 12 h. After the mixture cooled to the room temperature, the undissolved CB[6] was filtered. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuo to produce a colorless solid of pseudo-rotaxane named [PRBDM3](NO 3 ) 2 in which [H 2 BDMN3] 2+ was incorporated into the cavity of CB[6]. A solution of AgNO3 (17.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 5 mL of water was added to the solution of [PRBDM3](NO 3 ) 2 (62.8 mg, 0.04 mmol) in 5 mL of water. Light-brown X-ray quality crystals of 3 were obtained by slow evaporation of this mixture solution in 2 weeks (47%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O):  δ 8.82 (s, 2H), 8.46 (d, 2H), 8.17 (d, 2H), 7.43 (q, 2H), 6.34 (s, 4H), 5.50 (d, 12H), 5.33 (s, 12H), 4.49 (s, 4H), 4.32 (s, 4H), 4.10 (d, 12H). Anal. Calcd for AgC56H80N31O31:  C, 37.55; H, 4.50; N, 24.24. Found:  C, 37.52; H, 4.58; N, 24.32.

elements.content: Crystallography. The intensity data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a Siemens P4 four-circle diffractometer at 293 K, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SIR92. The intensity data for complexes 3 and 4 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS−RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SIR9224 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for complexes 1 − 4 are summarized in Table . Further details are provided in the Supporting Information.

Crystal Structure of pseudo-Rotaxane [(H 2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 2 ·H 2 O (1). The result of crystallographic analysis confirmed that the aliphatic chain of protonated C6N3 is included inside the cavity of CB[6] to form a pseudo-rotaxane structure. As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two [PR63](NO 3 ) 2 moieties, in forms A and B. In A, the dihedral angle between the plane of six portal carbonyl O atoms of CB[6] and the plane of the pyridyl group of [H 2 C6N3] 2+ is 67.20°, and in B the corresponding angle is 41.58°. Usually, CB[6] has a high D 6 h symmetrical structure; however, in A and B, CB[6] is distorted to some extent. As discussed by Samsonenko, the degree of distortion of CB[6] was judged by the difference of distance between the opposite carbon atoms of the CB[6] CH groups, thus the degrees of distortion of CB[6] in A and B are 0.35 and 0.46 Å, respectively. Due to more inclination of CB[6], the degree of distortion in B is larger than that in A. The protonated amine nitrogen atoms of [H 2 C6N3] 2+ protrude 0.90 Å in A and 0.80 Å in B outside the plane of the six portal carbonyl O atoms, respectively. The pseudo-rotaxane structure of [PR63] 2+ is stabilized by four intramolecular hydrogen bonds [N28···O2, 2.875(5) Å; N28···O3, 3.015(5) Å; N30···O11, 2.787(4) Å; N30···O12, 2.913(4) Å]. The hydrogen bonding data are summarized in Table S1 of the Supporting Information. The plane of pyridyl in A almost parallels the semi-glycoluril-ring of CB[6] in B with the center-to-center distance of 3.62 Å, which implies that there is π−π interaction between the above two planes (Figure b). Such π−π interactions make complex 1 an infinite 2D network structure (Figure b).

Results and Discussion

 Crystal Structure of pseudo-Rotaxane [(H  2  C6N3)(CB[6])](NO  3  )  2  ⋅H  2  O (1). The result of crystallographic analysis confirmed that the aliphatic chain of protonated C6N3 is included inside the cavity of CB[6] to form a pseudo-rotaxane structure. As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two [PR63](NO  3  )  2  moieties, in forms A and B. In A, the dihedral angle between the plane of six portal carbonyl O atoms of CB[6] and the plane of the pyridyl group of [H  2  C6N3]  2+   is 67.20°, and in B the corresponding angle is 41.58°. Usually, CB[6] has a high D 6  h  symmetrical structure; however, in A and B, CB[6] is distorted to some extent. As discussed by Samsonenko, the degree of distortion of CB[6] was judged by the difference of distance between the opposite carbon atoms of the CB[6] CH groups, thus the degrees of distortion of CB[6] in A and B are 0.35 and 0.46 Å, respectively. Due to more inclination of CB[6], the degree of distortion in B is larger than that in A. The protonated amine nitrogen atoms of [H  2  C6N3]  2+   protrude 0.90 Å in A and 0.80 Å in B outside the plane of the six portal carbonyl O atoms, respectively. The pseudo-rotaxane structure of [PR63]  2+   is stabilized by four intramolecular hydrogen bonds [N28⋅⋅⋅O2, 2.875(5) Å; N28⋅⋅⋅O3, 3.015(5) Å; N30⋅⋅⋅O11, 2.787(4) Å; N30⋅⋅⋅O12, 2.913(4) Å]. The hydrogen bonding data are summarized in Table S1 of the Supporting Information. The plane of pyridyl in A almost parallels the semi-glycoluril-ring of CB[6] in B with the center-to-center distance of 3.62 Å, which implies that there is π-π interaction between the above two planes (Figure b). Such π-π interactions make complex 1 an infinite 2D network structure (Figure b).

elements.content: Crystal Structure of Polyrotaxane [Ag(H 2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 3 ·8H 2 O (2). It is expected that the pseudo-rotaxane 1 can be linked by metal ions through the coordination with the pyridyl nitrogen atom of [H 2 C6N3] 2+ to generate a polyrotaxane or molecular necklace. Therefore, reaction of the pseudo-rotaxane with silver(I) nitrate was carried out, and complex 2 was isolated. The X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrated that 2 is an infinite 1D polyrotaxane with square-wave-like shape (Figures and a). Each silver(I) ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two pyridyl groups of two different [H 2 C6N3] 2+ with nearly linear coordination geometry as the N−Ag−N coordination angle is 164.15(18)° (Table ). The two coordinated pyridine planes with a dihedral angle of 54.60° have trans conformation since the two 3-pyridyl nitrogen atoms locate in opposite directions from the Ag(I) ion as exhibited in Scheme . The Ag1−N13 bond length of 2.357(4) Å (Table ) is longer than those reported silver(I) complexes with the homologous protonated diaminoalkane ligands. In addition, the Ag···O8 and Ag···O9 distances of 2.633(3) and 2.812(4) Å (Table S2, Supporting Information) indicate that there are weak interactions between the Ag1(I) ion and the oxygen atoms of the nitrate anion.

Interestingly, there are two intermolecular O−H···O hydrogen bonds with the O···O distances of 2.849(5) and 2.918(5) Å (Table S1, Supporting Information), formed by the oxygen atom of the uncoordinated water molecule and two carbonyl oxygen atoms of two CB[6] from two adjacent polyrotaxane chains, respectively. They generate an infinite 2D network structure of 2 (Figure a). Moreover, a similar π−π interaction to that in pseudo-rotaxane 1 was observed in 2, since the plane of pyridyl group in one chain almost parallels the semi-glycoluril-ring of CB[6] from another chain with the center-to-center distance of 3.60 Å (Figure a). The 2D networks pack together to give a 3D structure of 2, which was stabilized by ion−dipole interactions between the carbonyl C atom of CB[6] and the O atom of the nitrate anion [the C···O distances are 3.148(6) Å (Table S2, Supporting Information)] and C−H···O hydrogen bonds between the methylene C atoms of CB[6] and the O atoms of the nitrate anion or the lattice water molecule [the C···O distances are 3.166(6) and 3.123(7) Å, respectively (Table S1, Supporting Information)] (Figure b).

elements.content: Crystal Structure of Polyrotaxane [Ag(H 2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 3 ·10H 2 O (3). When [H 2 BDMN3] 2+ was used to replace the [H 2 C6N3] 2+ in 2, the central aromatic group was successfully included inside the cavity of CB[6] and the polyrotaxane 3 was obtained. As illustrated in Figure , polyrotaxane 3 also has two crystallographically independent units labeled with A and B like those in pseudo-rotaxane 1. Each Ag(I) ion with linear coordination geometry in 3 sits on an inversion center and is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two parallel pyridyl groups of two [H 2 BDMN3] 2+ ligands with trans conformation (Scheme ). Thus, both A and B in 3 show sawtooth-wave shaped 1D chain structures (Figures and a), rather than the square-wave shaped one in 2 as mentioned above. The Ag−N bond lengths of 2.170(6) Å (A) and 2.187(6) Å (B) (Table ) are shorter than those in 2 and the previously reported silver(I) complexes with the homologous protonated diaminoalkane ligands. Additionally, the silver(I) ion has weak interactions with the nitrate anions [the average Ag···O distance is 2.885 Å (Table S3, Supporting Information)] like those in 2.

elements.content: The carbonyl oxygen atoms of the CB[6] molecules (O106, O205) in two polyrotaxane chains of 3 form intermolecular O−H···O hydrogen bonds [the O···O distances are 2.78(13) and 2.90(12) Å (Table S1, Supporting Information)] with the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules to generate an infinite 2D network structure of 3 (Figure a), although the hydrogen atoms of lattice water molecules could not be found. In addition, the plane of the semi-glycoluril-ring of CB[6] in one chain parallels that of the semi-glycoluril-ring of CB[6] in another chain with the centroid−centroid separation of 3.78 Å, which indicates the presence of π−π interactions (Figure a). The C···O distances of 3.21(17) and 3.15(14) Å (Table S1, Supporting Information) indicate that there are two types of C−H···O hydrogen bonds; one is between the methylene C−H of CB[6] in one chain and the carbonyl oxygen atom of CB[6] in another chain, and the other is between methylene C−H of CB[6] and the oxygen atom of nitrate anion (Figure b). Moreover, there are ion−dipole interactions27 between carbonyl C atoms of CB[6] and O atoms of nitrate anions [the C···O distance of 2.89(11) Å (Table S3, Supporting Information)] (Figure b). Such interactions make the 3D structure of 3.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of Polyrotaxane [Ag(H 2 BDMN3)(CB[6])(H 2 O)][Ag(H 2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](ClO 4 ) 6 ·12H 2 O (4). To investigate the influence of the anion on the formation and structure of polyrotaxane, the silver(I) salt of perchlorate was used, and complex 4 was prepared. The X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that the crystal structure of polyrotaxane 4 has a distinct difference from that of polyrotaxane 3. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 4 consists of two crystallographically independent silver(I) ions, and there are three different pseudo-rotaxane units labeled with A, B, and C. In unit B, the two pyridyl nitrogen atoms coordinate with two different silver ions, Ag1 and Ag2, while in unit A, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms connect the same two Ag2(I) ions, and in unit C, they link two Ag1(I) ions. The Ag1(I) ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from the pyridine groups of B and C with N−Ag1−N angle of 156.42(15)° and one oxygen atom of water molecule with the N−Ag1−O angles 95.05(15)° and 104.97(15)° (Table ). Thus the coordination environment of the Ag1(I) ion can be regarded as a T-shaped coordination mode (Figure ). However, the Ag2(I) ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two pyridine groups of A and B with N−Ag2−N angle of 174.9(2)° (Table ), and the coordination environment of the Ag2(I) ion can be regarded as a linear coordination mode (Figure ). In addition, a Ag2···O51 distance of 2.70(10) Å indicates the occurrence of a weak interaction between the Ag2 ion and the oxygen atom of the perchlorate anion. The Ag−N bond lengths of 2.137(4) (Ag1−N11), 2.158(4) (Ag1−N31), 2.126(5) (Ag2−N21), and 2.119(5) Å (Ag2−N41) are shorter than those in 2 and 3 (Table ). Furthermore, the Ag(I) ions have weak interactions with the portal carbonyl O atoms of CB[6] in unit B [Ag1···O101 = 3.201(94) Å and Ag2···O108 = 3.080(86) Å (Table S4, Supporting Information)] (Figure ). It is noteworthy that the two pyridine groups coordinated to each Ag(I) ion with dihedral angle of 73.1° (coordinating with Ag1(I) ion) or 14.6° (coordinating with Ag2(I) ion) have cis conformation, while those observed in polyrotaxanes 2 and 3 are trans (Scheme ). Compared with 2, the difference of coordination modes of Ag(I) ions to ligands (Scheme ) leads to the formation of a different square-wave shaped 1D chain structure of 4. The 3D network structure of 4 is generated by the intermolecular O−H···O and C−H···O hydrogen bonds among the CB[6] molecules, lattice water molecules, and perchlorate anions. Additionally, the ion−dipole interactions27 between carbonyl C atoms of CB[6] molecules and O atoms of perchlorate anions help to stabilize the 3D structure of 4 (Tables S1 and S4, Supporting Information; Figure a,b). Unlike in 2 and 3, no π−π interactions were found in 4.

elements.content: Effects of Ligands (Guest Molecules) and Counterion s on the Structure of Polyrotaxanes. It is interesting to find that the polyrotaxanes 2, 3, and 4 have different shapes and structures (Figure ), which implies the impact of the ligands and the counteranions. Since the metal salts used in 2 and 3 are the same, namely, AgNO3, the various structural features of these two polyrotaxanes are most probably caused by their different spacers, that is, aliphatic chain [H 2 C6N3] 2+ in 2 or aromatic [H 2 BDMN3] 2+ in 3, between the two coordinating pyridyl groups of the ligands. While in the cases of complexes 3 and 4, the same organic ligand BDMN3 was employed and thus the different counteranions of nitrate or perchlorate may be responsible for the different structure of these two complexes.

elements.content: To compare the structural features of 2, 3, and 4 in detail, we define three structural parameters, θ1, θ2, and ω (Table , Scheme ), and the results of the calculated θ1, θ2, and ω values for 2, 3, and 4, together with the previously reported polyrotaxane [PR53] 2+ + AgNO3 15 are tabulated in Table . When θ1 is equal to θ2 and the two terminal pyridyl groups stretch to opposite directions of aliphatic or aromatic spacers (Scheme ), if ω is nearly equal to 0°, which means a nearly parallel arrangement of the CB[6] molecules in the polyrotaxane, the 1D chain of polyrotaxane is sawtooth-wave shaped; otherwise, it is square-wave shaped. According to these, the 1D structures of 2 and 4 are square-wave shaped, while the one of 3 is sawtooth-wave shaped (Table and Figure ). It is worth noting that the major difference between the square-wave shaped 2 or 4 and the sawtooth-wave shaped 3 is the arrangement of CB[6] molecules, that is, the values of ω.

elements.content: Structure Parameters for Pseudo-Rotaxane Units
elements.clean_text: 3  Structure Parameters for Pseudo-Rotaxane Units

elements.content:
Structure Parameters a (deg) for Pseudo-Rotaxane Units in Polyrotaxanes

a  θ1 and θ2 are the dihedral angles between the plane formed by atoms of the aliphatic or aromatic spacer and the plane of pyridine group in protonated diaminoalkane guest; ω is the dihedral angle between the planes of the six portal carbonyl O atoms of two adjacent CB[6] molecules. b  Reference 15.

On the other hand, when the structure parameter θ1 is not equal to θ2 and the two terminal pyridyl groups stretch to the same direction of aliphatic or aromatic spacers, the 1D chain structure of polyrotaxane has a trend to be helix as reported by K. Kim and co-workers. A helical 1D polyrotaxane was obtained by reaction of CB[6] and protonated N‘,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,5-pentanediamine ([H 2 C5N3] 2+ ) with AgNO3 (Table ). It has been suggested that the odd number of the carbon atoms in the aliphatic spacer of the [H 2 C5N3] 2+ and sp3 configuration of the carbon atoms led the terminal pyridyl groups toward the same direction. The asymmetric conformation of [PR53] 2+ (θ1 ≠ θ2 in Table ) is due to the unmatched distance between two protonated amine nitrogen atoms of fully extended [H 2 C5N3] 2+ and the separation between the portals of CB[6]. Therefore, Kim et al. proposed that both asymmetric and flexible ligands (guest molecules) might tend to form the helical structure.

elements.content: Compared with the C5N3, ligands C6N3 and BDMN3 have longer flexible carbon chain spacers; however, both of them form symmetric nonhelical structures when they thread into CB[6] molecules in 2, 3, and 4, in which the dihedral angles θ1 and θ2 are equal or almost equal except those in unit B of 4 (Table ) and the terminal two pyridyl groups bend in opposite directions (Scheme ). Therefore, We suggest that the even number of the carbon atoms in the aliphatic or aromatic spacer of the ligands not only results in terminal pyridyl groups' stretching in the opposite direction but also leads to the symmetric structure of polyrotaxane.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the crystal structures of one pseudo-rotaxane, 1, and three polyrotaxanes, 2, 3, and 4. Through π−π interactions, pseudo-rotaxane 1 generates an infinite 2D network structure. Linked by Ag(I) atoms, pseudo-rotaxane units of [PR63] 2+ or [PRBDM3] 2+ generate three 1D chain polyrotaxanes 2, 3, and 4, respectively. When the metal ions are the same, the shapes of the 1D chains are mainly affected by the flexibility of the spacers in the ligands, as well as the counteranions of the complexes. Intermolecular hydrogen bonds and π−π and dipole interactions formed among CB[6], guest molecules, uncoordinated water molecules, and counteranions play an obvious role in generating infinite 2D and 3D structures from 1D chains of the polyrotaxanes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, we report the crystal structures of one pseudo-rotaxane, 1, and three polyrotaxanes, 2, 3, and 4. Through π-π interactions, pseudo-rotaxane 1 generates an infinite 2D network structure. Linked by Ag(I) atoms, pseudo-rotaxane units of [PR63]  2+   or [PRBDM3]  2+   generate three 1D chain polyrotaxanes 2, 3, and 4, respectively. When the metal ions are the same, the shapes of the 1D chains are mainly affected by the flexibility of the spacers in the ligands, as well as the counteranions of the complexes. Intermolecular hydrogen bonds and π-π and dipole interactions formed among CB[6], guest molecules, uncoordinated water molecules, and counteranions play an obvious role in generating infinite 2D and 3D structures from 1D chains of the polyrotaxanes.

cln_elements.content:
Preparation of [(H 2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 2 ·H 2 O (1). A mixture of CB[6] (2.90 g, 2.91 mmol) and [H4 C6N3](NO3)4 (1.00 g, 1.82 mmol) in water (40 mL) was heated at 50 °C for 8 h. After the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight, the undissolved CB[6] was filtered off. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuo to give a colorless solid of pseudo-rotaxane named [PR63](NO 3 ) 2 in which [H 2 C6N3] 2+ was incorporated into the cavity of CB[6]. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of 1 were obtained from a solution of [PR63](NO 3 ) 2 (79.2 mg, 0.055 mmol) in 5 mL of water by methanol diffusion after 2 weeks (36%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O):  δ 9.24 (s, 2H), 9.03 (d, 2H), 8.91 (d, 2H), 8.22 (t, 2H), 5.71 (d, 12H), 5.60 (d, 12H), 4.74 (s, 4H), 4.34 (d, 12H), 3.14 (t, 4H), 0.82 (m, 4H), 0.52 (m, 4H). Anal. Calcd for C54H64N30O18·7H2O:  C, 41.91; H, 5.08; N, 27.16. Found:  C, 41.75; H, 4.78; N, 27.06.

[Ag(H 2 C6N3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 3 ·8H 2 O (2). AgNO3 (18.7 mg, 0.11 mmol) was added to a solution of [PR63](NO 3 ) 2 (79.2 mg, 0.055 mmol) in 5 mL of water. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture in 2 weeks produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 2 with yield of 40%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O):  δ 8.87 (s, 2H), 8.60 (d, 2H), 8.24 (d, 2H), 7.59 (t, 2H), 5.71 (d, 12H), 5.58 (d, 12H), 4.47 (s, 4H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 3.08 (t, 4H), 0.85 (m, 4H), 0.51 (m, 4H). Anal. Calcd for AgC54H80N31O29:  C, 37.38; H, 4.65; N, 25.02. Found:  C, 36.77; H, 3.81; N, 25.26.

[Ag(H 2 BDMN3)(CB[6])](NO 3 ) 3 ·10H 2 O (3). A mixture of CB[6] (3.98 g, 4.00 mmol) and [H4 BDMN3](NO3)4 (1.71 g, 3.00 mmol) in water (50 mL) was refluxed for 12 h. After the mixture cooled to the room temperature, the undissolved CB[6] was filtered. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuo to produce a colorless solid of pseudo-rotaxane named [PRBDM3](NO 3 ) 2 in which [H 2 BDMN3] 2+ was incorporated into the cavity of CB[6]. A solution of AgNO3 (17.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 5 mL of water was added to the solution of [PRBDM3](NO 3 ) 2 (62.8 mg, 0.04 mmol) in 5 mL of water. Light-brown X-ray quality crystals of 3 were obtained by slow evaporation of this mixture solution in 2 weeks (47%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O):  δ 8.82 (s, 2H), 8.46 (d, 2H), 8.17 (d, 2H), 7.43 (q, 2H), 6.34 (s, 4H), 5.50 (d, 12H), 5.33 (s, 12H), 4.49 (s, 4H), 4.32 (s, 4H), 4.10 (d, 12H). Anal. Calcd for AgC56H80N31O31:  C, 37.55; H, 4.50; N, 24.24. Found:  C, 37.52; H, 4.58; N, 24.32.

[Ag(H 2 BDMN3)(CB[6])(H 2 O)][Ag(H 2 BDMN3)](CB[6])](ClO 4 ) 6 ·12H 2 O (4). When a solution of [Ag(CH3CN)4]ClO4 (37.2 mg, 0.10 mmol) in water was used instead of AgNO3 in the above procedures for preparation of polyrotaxane 3, colorless X-ray quality crystals of 4 were obtained by slow evaporation of the solution in 2 weeks (52%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O):  δ 8.95 (s, 2H), 8.58 (d, 2H), 8.42 (d, 2H), 7.65 (q, 2H), 6.38 (s, 4H), 5.53 (d, 12H), 5.37 (s, 12H), 4.61 (s, 4H), 4.35 (s, 4H), 4.14 (d, 12H). Anal. Calcd for Ag2C112H146Cl6N56O61:  C, 36.54; H, 4.00; N, 21.31. Found:  C, 36.43; H, 4.02; N, 21.30.
